Award.AwardTitle: Participant Support for the Conference Building Bridges II
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will fund participation of US based researchers in the conference Building Bridges II, to be held July 2-6, 2018, at the MTA Renyi Institute of Mathematics, Budapest, Hungary. The conference will cover front line research achievements in combinatorics and its connections to other parts of mathematics. The objective of the award is to increase participation by leading junior researchers who otherwise do not have funding.

Among the wide variety of topics to be covered at the conference are graph homomorphisms and graph limits, a novel and exciting direction related to the study of large networks such as the internet; and additive combinatorics, an area that saw recent spectacular results and is connected to computer science. The conference website is https://www.renyi.hu//conferences/ll70/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant has been used to support young researchers to participate in a major conference in the field of combinatorics (Budapest, July 2018). 

Combinatorics is a new area of mathematics that has been under very impressive development in the last two decades, and has found surprising and powerful connections to many other, more established, areas of mathematics, such as number theory, probability, ergodic theory, random matrices etc. Many recent breakthoughts in theses areas have been made thanks to tools/ideas from combinatorics. This is an exciting time for young researchers to enter the field. 

 

The Budapest conference (marking the 70th birthday of Laszlo Lovasz, one of the creator of modern combinatorics) brought together top researchers from various areas, such as T. Tao, E. Szemeredi, and A. Wigderson. This was a unique opportunity for young researchers to listen to talks delivered by these very best leading scientists, and to build collaboration with other researchers from all over the world. 

It would be great if NSF supports more activities like this in the future. The cost is minimal (about 2K/person), but the impact can be for a life time. It would be even more efficient to run this kind of activities directly, not through universities, which complicate the while process quite a bit.
